content.description: This is a great crack climb which you will enjoy if you like cracks.  The first pitch is a hand crack, and the second pitch is a bigger crack which can be liebacked in some places.  You should save your #4 Camalot for about 3/4s of the way up the second pitch.  You can get to the top of the rock from the end of the second pitch, but it is not recommended.
content.protection:
A standard rack up to a #4 Camalot.  Extra #2 and #3 Camalots are good to have but not absolutely necessary.  There are bolt anchors.  The first shared with

Sills' Route

.
content.location:
This route is on the east face of the rock.  It is to the right of

Sills' Route

, and it starts up a hand crack.  You get down from bolt anchors on both pitches.

content.description: This is a fun route!  It is too bad that the approach takes an hour.  It probably does not get climbed very often.  The crux seems like it is between the first two bolts, but it is about the same in difficulty most of the way.  If you like slabs, you will like this route.
content.location:
This route is on the east face between two cracks.

Too High to Die

is to the right, and

Die Too High

is to the left.  You can get down from the bolts at the anchor at the top.

content.description: The crux is the start gaining the low angle crack to the summit.  A 30m rope is recommended for the route.
content.location:
The route is located on the west side of the summit block.  From the road used for the approach, climb up a class 3 gully to a notch located on the north side of the summit. Once at the notch, traverse west below a boulder onto a ledge.  The crack to the summit is obvious from the ledge as there is a small scrub at the start.

You can use a single 30m rope for the rappel from webbing located on a boulder near the summit.

climbs.name: Die Too High
climbs.fa: George Bracksieck and Claire Carren, Dec. 1977

content.description:
This is the easiest way to the

Sills' Route

anchor.  It is a fairly fun route and is protectable along its length.  You move to the left about 3/4s of the way up on a good, protectable ledge.  The crack is smaller than a hand crack for most of its length.
content.protection:
Standard rack,  1 fixed pin.  The anchor is shared with

Sills' Route

at the top.
content.location:
This is on the east face of the rock to the left of

Sills' Route

.  The crack starts well below

Sills' Route

, but you can do a leftward friction traverse to the crack if you do not want to climb down to its start.  You get down from the bolted anchor on

Sills' Route

.
